conclusion: Problem involves finding elevator speed at t=60 seconds using acceleration-time graph.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity; velocity is the integral of acceleration.
Graph shows acceleration vs. time with specific points and intervals.
From t=0 to t=1 second, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t=1 to t=4 seconds, acceleration remains constant at 2 m/s².
From t=4 to t=5 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t=5 to t=55 seconds, acceleration is 0.
From t=55 to t=56 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t=56 to t=59 seconds, acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s².
From t=59 to t=60 seconds, acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.
Elevator starts from rest, initial velocity is 0 m/s.
Velocity at t=60 seconds is found by calculating area under acceleration-time graph.
Section 1 (t=0 to t=1): Triangle area = 1 m/s.
Section 2 (t=1 to t=4): Rectangle area = 6 m/s.
Section 3 (t=4 to t=5): Triangle area = 1 m/s.
Section 4 (t=5 to t=55): Area = 0.
Section 5 (t=55 to t=56): Triangle area = -1 m/s.
Section 6 (t=56 to t=59): Rectangle area = -6 m/s.
Section 7 (t=59 to t=60): Triangle area = -1 m/s.
Sum of areas: 1 + 6 + 1 + 0 - 1 - 6 - 1 = 0 m/s.
Velocity at t=60 seconds is 0 m/s.
Double-checking areas confirms calculations.
